tags.heading: Header Tag
tags.desc: Represents a container for introductory content or navigational links. Typically contains one or more heading elements (`<h1>` - `<h6>`) or logo.

tags.heading: Navigation Tag
tags.desc: A section of the page intended for navigation links.

tags.heading: Main Tag
tags.desc: Represents the main content of the `<body>`. There should only be one `<main>` element per document.

tags.heading: Section Tag
tags.desc: A standalone section of content which can have a heading.

tags.heading: Article Tag
tags.desc: Represents a self-contained piece of content that can be independently distributed or reused (blog post, news article).

tags.heading: Aside Tag
tags.desc: Represents content that is indirectly related to the surrounding content. (sidebars).

tags.heading: Footer Tag
tags.desc: Represents the footer for its closest section or the whole page. It usually contains information about the author, copyright details, or links to related documents.
Represents self-contained content, like images, diagrams, or code snippets, usually with a caption.
Provides a caption or legend for the content of the `<figure>`.

why.title: Accessibility
why.desc: Using semantic tags helps screen readers and other tools understand the layout and content of the page, making it easier for everyone to use.

why.title: SEO
why.desc: Search engines can better understand and rank your content when you use semantic tags.

why.title: Maintainability
why.desc: Semantic tags make your HTML code cleaner and easier for developers to work with.

why.title: Standardization
why.desc: Using semantic HTML follows web standards, ensuring your site works well across different browsers.
